item.title: Maximizing First Call Resolution (FCR): The Number One Priority for Customers
item.description: Photo source: Interactive Powers Consumers rank first-contact resolution as the most valued aspect of a service interaction, yet CX leaders rank it ninth In the competitive world of customer service, a key metric or Key Performance Indicator (KPI) stands out: First Call Resolution (FCR). Customers not only expect quick solutions—ideally, speaking with an agent within 1 to 10 minutes—but they also expect to resolve their query in that first interaction.

item.title: Net Promoter Score (NPS)
item.description: Photo source: Interactive Powers How does NPS differ from Phone and Video interactions in your Call / Contact Center? What is a Net Promoter Score (NPS)? The Net Promoter Score (NPS) is an index ranging from -100 to 100 that measures the willingness of customers to recommend a company’s products or services to others. It is used as a proxy for gauging the customer’s overall satisfaction with a company’s product or service and the customer’s loyalty to the brand.

item.title: Customer Effort Score (CES)
item.description: Photo source: Interactive Powers How does CES differ from Phone and Video interactions in your Call / Contact Center? What is a Customer Effort Score (CES)? A Customer Effort Score (CES) is a service metric that measures how much effort customers put in to interact with your business. These interactions can be something like how much effort it takes to use your product or service or how easy it was for them to have a problem solved by your service reps.

item.title: Average Handle Time Score (AHT)
item.description: Photo source: Interactive Powers How does AHT differ from Phone and Video interactions in your Call / Contact Center? What is a Average Handle Time Score (AHT)? When you work in customer support, you know how important it is to optimize your handle times. But while it’s clearly important to reduce average handling time at a Call / Contact Center, it’s not always that simple. Average handle time (AHT) is, as you’ve probably guessed, the average amount of time that a customer call takes from start to finish a process.

item.title: First Call Resolution Score (FCR)
item.description: Photo source: Interactive Powers How does FCR differ from Phone and Video interactions in your Call / Contact Center? What is a First Call Resolution Score (FCR)? The First Call Resolution (FCR) can come in handy as one of many important metrics to keep track of in the pursuit of exceptional customer service. Furthermore, FCR measures a company’s ability to resolve phone calls, chats, emails, video calls, and website customer interactions resolved on the first contact.

item.title: Customer Satisfaction Score (CSAT)
item.description: Photo source: Interactive Powers How does CSAT differ from Phone and Video interactions in your Call / Contact Center? What is a Customer Satisfaction Score (CSAT)? A big strength of Customer Satisfaction Score (CSTA) is an easy way to close the loop on a customer interaction and determine whether or not it was effective in producing happiness. If for some reason the experience wasn’t satisfactory, it’s easy to pinpoint that moment and take actions to remedy the experience.

item.title: Video Calls · Scheduled vs Queued
item.description: Photo source: Interactive Powers. Creative Commons Why most companies have to change their mind about Video Calls productivity and integration? Existing “Video Meeting” solutions are used by most people for teleworking, remote business meeting or friends & family conversations (Zoom, Teams, LifeSize, Google Meet…). All these products are design to build conversations with a scheduled approach one-to-many or one-to-one. Companies that provide support to many customers do not work like this most of the time, they have to react in real-time to a massive inbound and outbound customers requests.

item.title: Time is Money on Customer Experience
item.description: Photo source: Unplash. Creative Commons Customer expectations are growing every day and two of the key factors are time and effort. item.title: The Age of the Customer in Contact Centers
